Anyway, you're piloting a little lander-probe through another universe. This universe gets its name from it's own incredible smallness. (The entire universe is just 0.1 light-years across, and the planets are 150 meters!)

Lava tides/waves don't really make sense in a universe where gravity is static.

Lava tides/waves don't really make sense in a universe where gravity is static.

There would be tides, just unchanging ones. The sphere of liquid would be slightly distended. Waves don't have to be caused by tidal forces though here, there would be a lot of convection going on, as well as perhaps some manner of direct effect from the proximity of the sun. Lava planets will need boiling atmospheres too from outgassing of the melted rocks.

edit: I do agree the waves are too vigorous, I've greatly reduced the deformation and made it a lot more subtle now. Looks better.
